item.title: What programming language should I learn first (as a maths student)?
item.description: This post summarises my answer to a common question I get from mathematics students. I’m not dogmatic about this; I recommend either R, Julia or Python depending on your project and specialisation. If youâ€™re doing statistics, R is a no-brainer. For machine-learning heavy work, Python is still the standard. For more general numerical computing and simulation, for example Monte Carlo and MCMC (most of what I research day to day) I recommend Julia now because these things need to be fast.

item.title: Advanced Stochastic Modelling and Monte Carlo Methods
item.description: In Semester 1 this year, I will again be teaching an honours course which I have roughly titled: Advanced Stochastic Modelling and Monte Carlo Methods. For those of you considering it, this post gives an outline of the topics I intend to cover this year. Due to the restrictions on in-person teaching and workload constraints, all honours courses will be run as reading courses this year. This means there will be no lectures and instead a single weekly workshop.

item.title: Applied Probability at the Rock
item.description: I created the poster for the upcoming Applied Probability conference being held for Phil Pollett’s 60’th birthday. Inspired by some of Anders Hoff’s work, I tried to capture the layer structure of Uluru using a line tracing algorithm written in Processing, which uses Java behind the scenes. Roughly, it starts with a straight line and then tries to copy this, but with some noise added. After many iterations larger scale patterns start to emerge.
